US says it has right to kidnap foreign citizens
David Leppard
The US has told Britain it can kidnap foreign citizens if they are wanted for crimes in the US. A senior lawyer for the US government told the court of appeal in London that kidnapping foreign citizens is permissible under US law because the US Supreme Court has sanctioned it. Until now, it was assumed that US law permitted kidnapping only in the extraordinary rendition of terror suspects. The US government has, for the first time, made it clear that the law applies to anyone suspected of a crime by Washington. Legal experts confirmed this weekend that the US viewed extradition as just one way of getting foreign suspects back to face trial. The US governments view emerged during a hearing involving Stanley Tollman, a former director of Chelsea football club and his wife Beatrice. The Tollmans, who control the Red Carnation hotel group and live in London, are wanted in the US for bank fraud. They have been fighting extradition through the British courts. During a hearing last month, Lord Justice Moses asked US government counsel Alun Jones about the US governments treatment of Gavin, Tollmans nephew. Gavin Tollman was the subject of an attempted abduction during a visit to Canada in 2005. Jones replied it was acceptable under US law to kidnap people if they were wanted for offences in the US. The US does have a view about procuring people to its own shores which is not shared. He said that if a person was kidnapped by the US authorities in another country and was brought back to face charges in the US, no US court could rule that the abduction was illegal and free him. If you kidnap a person outside the US and you bring him there, the court has no jurisdiction to refuse. It goes back to bounty-hunting days in the 1860s, Jones said. Justice Ouseley, a second judge, challenged Jones to be honest about (his) position. Jones replied: That is US law. SUNDAY TIMES, LONDON UNCLE SAM WANTS YOU Bounty hunting | A term that goes back to the 1860s. A bounty-hunter, traditionally employed by a bail bondsman, tracks down and captures outlaws for which he gets a reward Extraordinary rendition | Term used to describe kidnapping & extrajudicial transfer of a person, especially terror suspect, from one nation to another Case in Question | Former director of Chelsea football club Stanley Tollman and his wife, Beatrice, who are wanted in the US for fraud and tax evasion. US counsel justifies an abduction bid on Tollmans nephew, Gavin, in Canada in 2005 during a vacation. He was released by a Canadian court after 10 days
